FINANCIAL SONAR™: REALITY RADAR ON COMPANY PERFORMANCE NASDAQQGS NVDA NVIDIA CORPORATION OVERALL RATING FOR 1ST QUARTER 2026 HOLD REGION NORTH AMERICA INDUSTRY SEMICONDUCTORS AND SEMICONDUCTOR EQUIPMENT **OUR EVALUATION OF NVDA** NVIDIA Corporation is showing strong Earnings Quality, Cash Flow Quality, Operating Efficiency and Balance Sheet Quality, but Valuation suggests a higher amount of price risk. When combined, NVDA deserves a HOLD rating. The Operating Efficiency rating improved on the strength of better margins. Though this dimension and all of the others were either stronger or unchanged at worst, it was not sufficient to raise the overall rating. Summary : This figure presents a "Financial Sonar" radar chart for NVIDIA (NVDA) for the 1st quarter of 2026, visually assessing five financial dimensions: Valuation, Earnings Quality, Cash Flow Quality, Operating Efficiency, and Balance Sheet, with risk and strength levels indicated. radar chart: Title & Axes : • Title: "FINANCIAL SONAR™ FOR NVDA 1ST QUARTER 2026". • Five axes: Valuation, Earnings Quality, Cash Flow Quality, Operating Efficiency, Balance Sheet. • No explicit numeric scales; qualitative zones are shown (e.g., "Most Risk", "Strong", "Strongest"). Sectors & Labels : • Valuation (red sector): labeled "Most Risk". • Earnings Quality (green sector): labeled "Strongest". • Cash Flow Quality (green sector): labeled "Strongest". • Operating Efficiency (blue sector): labeled "Strong". • Balance Sheet (blue sector): labeled "Strong". Design Encodings : • Colour coding: red for risk (Valuation), green for quality (Earnings, Cash Flow), blue for strength (Operating Efficiency, Balance Sheet). • Concentric rings indicate qualitative gradations (e.g., "Most Risk", "Strong", "Strongest"). • Sectors are separated by bold lines. Analysis : • The chart indicates that NVDA's greatest financial risk in Q1 2026 is in Valuation. • The company is rated "Strongest" in both Earnings Quality and Cash Flow Quality. • Operating Efficiency and Balance Sheet are rated as "Strong". • The visual highlights a contrast between high risk in Valuation and strong performance in other financial dimensions. FINANCIAL SONAR™: REALITY RADAR ON COMPANY PERFORMANCE NASDAQQGS NVDA NVIDIA CORPORATION ────────────────────────────── OVERALL RATING FOR 1ST QUARTER 2026 HOLD REGION NORTH AMERICA INDUSTRY SEMICONDUCTORS AND SEMICONDUCTOR EQUIPMENT EARNINGS QUALITY: STRONGEST Earnings quality has long been analyzed and used by investors as a measure of the fundamental quality of the company and its future prospects. Companies may be including certain items that increase reported earnings and often the amount of cash flow supporting the earnings may be weak. Jefferson adjusts for these kinds of items and other anomalies to produce an adjusted earnings number that more accurately reflects ongoing business fundamentals at NVIDIA Corporation. Reported earnings are compared to the Jefferson adjusted earnings as a means to gauge earnings quality. Also measured is the amount of cash flow that underpins earnings. The earnings quality for NVDA remains STRONGEST. Though the reported net income dropped to 18,775M from 22,091M in the previous quarter, the quality of that reported net income improved. In addition, operating cash flow increased during the last quarter to 27,414M from 16,629M, and the ratio of operating cash flow to earnings has also improved. Though both Earnings Quality measures improved, the rating for NVDA is already a STRONGEST, the best possible rating. Summary : This bar chart compares net income and adjusted net income (in millions) across fiscal years 2024, 2025, the trailing 12 months, and quarterly periods Q4 2025 and Q1 2026, also showing adjusted net income as a percentage of net income. bar chart: Title & Axes : • Title: "NET INCOME VS. ADJUSTED NET INCOME" • Y-axis: Value in millions (0 to 75,000+) • X-axis: Time periods—Fiscal Year 2024, Fiscal Year 2025, Trailing 12 Months, Q4 2025, Q1 2026 Data Points : • Fiscal Year 2024: Net Income = 29,760.0; Adjusted Net Income = 28,789.4; Percentage = 96.7% • Fiscal Year 2025: Net Income = 72,880.0; Adjusted Net Income = 70,434.1; Percentage = 96.6% • Trailing 12 Months: Net Income = 76,774.0; Adjusted Net Income = 74,410.7; Percentage = 96.9% • Q4 2025: Net Income = 22,901.0; Adjusted Net Income = 21,001.2; Percentage = 95.1% • Q1 2026: Net Income = 18,175.0; Adjusted Net Income = 18,487.9; Percentage = 98.5% Design Encodings : • Net Income: grey bars • Adjusted Net Income: red triangle markers (Δ) above bars • Adjusted Net Income as a Percentage of Net Income: shown as text above each pair of bars • All values in millions Distribution & Trends : • Both net income and adjusted net income increase from Fiscal Year 2024 to the Trailing 12 Months, then are shown for two subsequent quarters. • Adjusted net income is consistently slightly lower than net income, except in Q1 2026 where it is slightly higher. • The percentage of adjusted net income to net income remains in a narrow range (95.1% to 98.5%). Analysis : • The data shows a general increase in both net income and adjusted net income from Fiscal Year 2024 to the Trailing 12 Months. • Adjusted net income closely tracks net income, with the gap narrowing in Q1 2026 where adjusted net income slightly exceeds net income. • The percentage of adjusted net income to net income is relatively stable, indicating minimal adjustments over the periods shown. Summary : This bar chart compares earnings and reported operating cash flow (in millions) across several time periods, showing operating cash flow as a percentage of earnings and highlighting trends in both metrics. bar chart: Title & Axes : • Title: "Earnings vs. Operating Cash Flow" • Y-axis: Value in millions (0 to 75,000, tick at 75,000) • X-axis: Time periods—Fiscal Year 2024, Fiscal Year 2025, Trailing 12 Months, Q4 2025, Q1 2026 Data Points : • Fiscal Year 2024: Earnings = 29,760.0; Reported Operating Cash Flow = 28,090.0; Percentage = 94.4% • Fiscal Year 2025: Earnings = 72,880.0; Reported Operating Cash Flow = 64,089.0; Percentage = 87.9% • Trailing 12 Months: Earnings = 76,774.0; Reported Operating Cash Flow = 76,158.0; Percentage = 99.2% • Q4 2025: Earnings = 22,091.0; Reported Operating Cash Flow = 16,629.0; Percentage = 75.3% • Q1 2026: Earnings = 18,775.0; Reported Operating Cash Flow = 27,414.0; Percentage = 146.0% Design Encodings : • Earnings shown as solid bars (grey/blue shades) • Reported Operating Cash Flow shown as red triangle markers • Percentages of operating cash flow to earnings displayed above each group • All values in millions Distribution & Trends : • Both earnings and operating cash flow generally increase from FY2024 to the trailing 12 months. • In Q4 2025, both metrics drop sharply. • In Q1 2026, reported operating cash flow exceeds earnings, resulting in a percentage over 100%. Analysis : • Operating cash flow closely tracks earnings in most periods, with percentages near or just below 100%. • Q4 2025 shows a notable dip in both earnings and cash flow, with the lowest percentage (75.3%). • Q1 2026 is an outlier, where operating cash flow (27,414.0) significantly exceeds earnings (18,775.0), resulting in a high percentage (146.0%). • The chart highlights a general trend of increasing values, with a sharp reversal and then a cash flow spike relative to earnings in the most recent quarter. Summary : This bar chart compares actual accruals and forecasted accruals as a percentage of sales across quarterly periods from Q2 2024 to Q1 2026. bar chart: Title & Axes : • Title: "ACCRUALS % OF SALES". • X-axis: Quarterly periods (Q2 2024, Q3 2024, Q4 2024, Q1 2025, Q2 2025, Q3 2025, Q4 2025, Q1 2026). • Y-axis: Percentage of sales (0.0% to 40.0%, ticked at 10% intervals). Data Points : • Actual Accruals (dark blue bars): – Q2 2024: 35.1% – Q3 2024: 29.2% – Q4 2024: 25.1% – Q1 2025: 22.9% – Q2 2025: 25.0% – Q3 2025: 25.2% – Q4 2025: 25.4% – Q1 2026: 23.9% • Forecasted Accruals (light pink bars): – Q2 2024: 34.2% – Q3 2024: 35.7% – Q4 2024: 33.6% – Q1 2025: 29.9% – Q2 2025: 25.9% – Q3 2025: 23.9% – Q4 2025: 22.8% – Q1 2026: 22.6% Design Encodings : • Actual Accruals: dark blue bars. • Forecasted Accruals: light pink bars. • Both series are grouped by quarter for direct comparison. • Data labels (percentages) are shown on each bar. Distribution & Trends : • Both actual and forecasted accruals generally decrease over time. • Actual accruals start higher than forecasted in Q2 2024, then fall below forecasted values from Q3 2024 through Q1 2025. • From Q2 2025 onward, actual accruals are consistently higher than forecasted accruals. Analysis : • There is a downward trend in both actual and forecasted accruals as a percentage of sales from Q2 2024 to Q1 2026. • The gap between actual and forecasted accruals fluctuates, with actuals initially above, then below, and finally above forecasted values in later quarters. • The largest discrepancy occurs in Q3 2024, where forecasted accruals (35.7%) significantly exceed actual accruals (29.2%). • By Q1 2026, both actual and forecasted accruals converge to similar values (23.9% actual vs. 22.6% forecasted). © 2025 Jefferson Research & Management Report prepared on **July 11, 2025** **Page 2 of 11** www.jeffersonresearch.com logo: Jefferson Research Design Elements : • The logo consists of three stylized maroon diagonal marks to the left of the text. • The text "Jefferson Research" appears in a dark blue serif font. • The logo is horizontally oriented, with the icon on the left and the company name on the right. • The background is white, and the text is clear and legible. Analysis : • The use of maroon and dark blue suggests a professional and academic brand identity. The serif font and simple iconography convey trustworthiness and research-oriented values. FINANCIAL SONAR™: REALITY RADAR ON COMPANY PERFORMANCE NASDAQGS NVDA NVIDIA CORPORATION OVERALL RATING FOR 1ST QUARTER 2026 HOLD REGION NORTH AMERICA INDUSTRY SEMICONDUCTORS AND SEMICONDUCTOR EQUIPMENT CASH FLOW QUALITY: STRONGEST Cash flow is considered by many investors to be the ultimate measure of company performance and more reliable than reported earnings. The Jefferson measurement eliminates items that are not part of recurring cash flow or the result of actual operations for NVIDIA Corporation. These adjustments to cash flow provide a truer measure of cash flow and the resultant cash flow quality rating. The cash flow quality rating for NVDA remains STRONGEST as the operating cash flow quality year over year improved. Even though the annual operating cash flow quality improved this fiscal year with a reported number of 64,089M and an adjusted number that was 100.4% of reported, the decline in the quarterly operating cash flow quality offset this with a reported number of 27,414M and an adjusted number that was 102.9% of reported. This represents deterioration from the previous period when the reported number was closer to the adjusted number. Summary : This bar chart compares operating cash flow and adjusted operating cash flow (in millions) across different fiscal periods, including Fiscal Year 2024, Fiscal Year 2025, the trailing 12 months, Q4 2025, and Q1 2026. It also presents adjusted operating cash flow as a percentage of operating cash flow for each period. bar chart: Title & Axes : • Title: "OPERATING CASH FLOW" • Y-axis: Cash flow in millions (values range from 0 to 75,000) • X-axis: Time periods—Fiscal Year 2024, Fiscal Year 2025, Trailing 12 Months, Q4 2025, Q1 2026 Data Points : • Fiscal Year 2024: Operating Cash Flow = 28,900.0; Adjusted Operating Cash Flow = 27,308.0; Percentage = 97.2% • Fiscal Year 2025: Operating Cash Flow = 64,089.0; Adjusted Operating Cash Flow = 64,331.0; Percentage = 100.4% • Trailing 12 Months: Operating Cash Flow = 76,158.0; Adjusted Operating Cash Flow = 76,490.0; Percentage = 100.4% • Q4 2025: Operating Cash Flow = 16,629.0; Adjusted Operating Cash Flow = 16,043.0; Percentage = 96.5% • Q1 2026: Operating Cash Flow = 27,414.0; Adjusted Operating Cash Flow = 28,215.0; Percentage = 102.9% Design Encodings : • Operating Cash Flow shown as solid bars (grey for annual/12-month, blue for quarters) • Adjusted Operating Cash Flow shown as red triangles above bars • Percentages of adjusted to operating cash flow shown above each period • All values labeled directly on the bars or above triangles Distribution & Trends : • Both cash flow measures increase sharply from FY2024 to FY2025 and peak in the trailing 12 months. • Q4 2025 shows a dip compared to annual values, but Q1 2026 rebounds. • Adjusted operating cash flow closely tracks or slightly exceeds operating cash flow in most periods. Analysis : • The adjusted operating cash flow is consistently close to or slightly above the reported operating cash flow, with percentages ranging from 96.5% to 102.9%. • The largest cash flow values occur in the trailing 12 months, indicating a period of strong performance. • Q4 2025 is a relative low point, but Q1 2026 shows a significant increase. • The close alignment between adjusted and reported values suggests minimal adjustments or non-recurring items. Summary : This bar chart presents Free Cash Flow and Adjusted Free Cash Flow (in millions) for several time periods, including Fiscal Years 2024 and 2025, Trailing 12 Months, Q4 2025, and Q1 2026, along with the percentage of Adjusted Free Cash Flow as a proportion of Free Cash Flow. bar chart: # Title & Axes : • Title: "FREE CASH FLOW" • Y-axis: Free Cash Flow (in millions), ranging from 0 to 75,000. • X-axis: Time periods—Fiscal Year 2024, Fiscal Year 2025, Trailing 12 Months, Q4 2025, Q1 2026. # Data Points : • Fiscal Year 2024: – Free Cash Flow: 26,626.0 – Adjusted Free Cash Flow: 25,844.0 – Percentage: 97.1% • Fiscal Year 2025: – Free Cash Flow: 60,019.0 – Adjusted Free Cash Flow: 60,261.0 – Percentage: 100.4% • Trailing 12 Months: – Free Cash Flow: 71,084.0 – Adjusted Free Cash Flow: 71,416.0 – Percentage: 100.5% • Q4 2025: – Free Cash Flow: 15,307.0 – Adjusted Free Cash Flow: 14,721.0 – Percentage: 102.8% • Q1 2026: – Free Cash Flow: 25,943.0 – Adjusted Free Cash Flow: 26,744.0 – Percentage: 103.1% # Design Encodings : • Free Cash Flow shown as solid bars. • Adjusted Free Cash Flow indicated by a triangle marker (Δ) above each bar. • Bars are colored in dark blue (Q1 2026) and gray (other periods). • Percentages are listed above each period. • All values are labeled directly on the bars. # Distribution & Trends : • Free Cash Flow and Adjusted Free Cash Flow generally increase from Fiscal Year 2024 to Trailing 12 Months, then decrease in Q4 2025, and rise again in Q1 2026. • Adjusted Free Cash Flow closely tracks or slightly exceeds Free Cash Flow in most periods. # Analysis : • Adjusted Free Cash Flow is consistently very close to or slightly above Free Cash Flow, with the percentage ranging from 97.1% to 103.1%. • The largest values are observed in the Trailing 12 Months period. • Q4 2025 shows the lowest values among the periods after Fiscal Year 2024. • The data suggests stable or improving cash flow performance, with minor adjustments between the two metrics. Summary : This line chart shows the flow ratio over time from Q2 2024 to Q1 2026, highlighting quarterly changes and trends. line chart: Title & Axes : • Title: "FLOW RATIO". • X-axis: Quarterly periods from Q2 24 to Q1 26 (labels: Q2 24, Q3 24, Q4 24, Q1 25, Q2 25, Q3 25, Q4 25, Q1 26). • Y-axis: Flow ratio (no explicit units), range from 0.00 to 2.00, with tick marks at 0.00, 0.50, 1.00, 1.50, and 2.00. Data Points : • Single series (no legend or series name). • Approximate values (from visual estimation): – Q2 24: ~1.15 – Q3 24: ~1.55 – Q4 24: ~1.65 – Q1 25: ~1.40 – Q2 25: ~1.80 – Q3 25: ~1.80 – Q4 25: ~2.10 – Q1 26: ~1.35 Design Encodings : • Solid dark line for data series. • Area under the line is shaded in light blue. • Bold font for the final x-axis label "Q1 26". • No gridlines except for faint horizontal reference lines. Distribution & Trends : • The flow ratio increases from Q2 24 to Q4 24, dips in Q1 25, rises again to a peak in Q4 25, then drops sharply in Q1 26. • Highest value at Q4 25 (~2.10), lowest at Q2 24 (~1.15). Analysis : • The flow ratio shows a cyclical pattern with two local peaks (Q4 24 and Q4 25) and a notable drop after the Q4 25 peak. • The most significant increase occurs between Q1 25 and Q4 25, followed by the steepest decline into Q1 26. • The data suggests possible seasonality or periodic fluctuations in the flow ratio across the observed quarters. Summary : This line chart shows the trend of Cash Flow ROI and Adjusted Cash Flow ROI from Q2 2024 to Q1 2026, highlighting their growth and fluctuations over time. line chart: Title & Axes : • Title: "CASH FLOW ROI" • Y-axis: Percentage scale labeled from 0.0% to 100.0%, with tick marks at 0.0%, 25.0%, 50.0%, 75.0%, and 100.0%. • X-axis: Quarterly periods labeled as Q2 24, Q3 24, Q4 24, Q1 25, Q2 25, Q3 25, Q4 25, and Q1 26. Data Points : • Two series: – Solid line: Cash Flow ROI (shaded area under the curve). – Dashed red line: Adjusted Cash Flow ROI (closely tracks the solid line). • Both series start near 25% in Q2 24, rise steadily to about 65% by Q1 25, peak around 75% in Q3 25, dip slightly in Q4 25, and end above 75% in Q1 26. Design Encodings : • Cash Flow ROI: solid line with blue shaded area beneath. • Adjusted Cash Flow ROI: red dashed line. • Both lines closely overlap throughout the period. Distribution & Trends : • Both series show a steady increase from Q2 24 to Q3 25. • There is a slight dip in Q4 25. • Both series recover and reach their highest point in Q1 26. Analysis : • Cash Flow ROI and Adjusted Cash Flow ROI both exhibit strong upward trends over the observed quarters, with only a minor dip in Q4 25 before reaching new highs in Q1 26. The adjusted and unadjusted values are nearly identical throughout, indicating minimal adjustment impact. Summary : This line chart shows the progression of debt coverage and adjusted debt coverage from Q2 2024 to Q1 2026, with values increasing steadily over time. line chart: Title & Axes : • Title: "DEBT COVERAGE" • Subtitle/Legend: "Adjusted Debt Coverage" • X-axis: Quarterly periods from Q2 24 to Q1 26 (labels: Q2 24, Q3 24, Q4 24, Q1 25, Q2 25, Q3 25, Q4 25, Q1 26) • Y-axis: Debt coverage values (no explicit units), tick labels at 0, 250, 500, 750 Data Points : • Solid line: Debt Coverage (exact values not labeled, but trend is visible) • Dashed red line: Adjusted Debt Coverage (closely tracks the solid line) • Both series start near 50 in Q2 24 and rise to approximately 750 by Q1 26 Design Encodings : • Solid black line for Debt Coverage • Dashed red line for Adjusted Debt Coverage • Shaded area under the lines (light blue) • No error bars or confidence intervals Distribution & Trends : • Both series show a steady, accelerating increase over time • The gap between the two lines is minimal throughout the period Analysis : • Debt coverage and adjusted debt coverage both rise consistently from Q2 2024 to Q1 2026, reaching their highest value (~750) at Q1 2026. • The adjusted debt coverage closely matches the unadjusted series, indicating minimal adjustment effect. • The growth appears nonlinear, with a steeper increase after Q1 25. © 2025 Jefferson Research & Management Report prepared on **July 11, 2025** **Page 3 of 11** www.jeffersonresearch.com logo: Jefferson Research • The image displays the logo for "Jefferson Research". • The logo consists of three stylized maroon diagonal marks to the left, followed by the company name "Jefferson Research" in a bold serif font, colored in dark blue. • The logo is on a white background, with the icon and text horizontally aligned. • No tagline or additional text is present. FINANCIAL SONAR™: REALITY RADAR ON COMPANY PERFORMANCE NASDAQQGS NVDA NVIDIA CORPORATION ──────────────────────────── OVERALL RATING FOR 1ST QUARTER 2026 HOLD REGION NORTH AMERICA INDUSTRY SEMICONDUCTORS AND SEMICONDUCTOR EQUIPMENT OPERATING EFFICIENCY: STRONG The ability of NVIDIA Corporation to earn a profit is in part the result of how rapidly it converts its collection of assets into revenues and the resulting earnings and cash flow margins available. Operating Efficiency is measured by a combination of factors including: return on invested capital (ROIC), gross margin, EBIT margin, asset turnover, equity turnover, and lastly Staff, General, and Administrative costs as a percentage of sales (SGA). The operating efficiency rating for NVDA improved from WEAK to STRONG as the return on incremental investment capital and SGA costs improved since the last quarter. In addition, the SGA costs improved from 2.5% to 2.4% of sales. The lower SGA costs indicate that NVDA has decreased the amount of revenue devoted to overhead costs. Summary : This line chart shows the gross margin percentage over time from Q2 2024 to Q1 2026, highlighting a recent downward trend. line chart: Title & Axes : • Title: "GROSS MARGIN" • X-axis: Quarters from Q2 24 to Q1 26 (labels: Q2 24, Q3 24, Q4 24, Q1 25, Q2 25, Q3 25, Q4 25, Q1 26) • Y-axis: Gross margin percentage (tick labels: 60.0%, 65.0%, 70.0%, 75.0%, 80.0%) Data Points : • Single series (gross margin % by quarter): – Q2 24: ~69.0% – Q3 24: ~73.0% – Q4 24: ~75.5% – Q1 25: ~78.0% (peak) – Q2 25: ~74.5% – Q3 25: ~74.0% – Q4 25: ~72.5% – Q1 26: ~60.0% (sharp drop) Design Encodings : • Solid black line with area under the curve shaded in light blue. • "Change from previous quarter: DOWN" in red text with a downward arrow. • Q1 26 label in bold black. Distribution & Trends : • Gross margin rises steadily from Q2 24 to a peak in Q1 25. • Gradual decline from Q1 25 to Q4 25. • Very sharp drop from Q4 25 to Q1 26. Analysis : • The gross margin increased from Q2 24 to Q1 25, peaking at around 78.0%. • After Q1 25, the margin declined slightly until Q4 25. • There is a dramatic decrease in gross margin in Q1 26, falling to approximately 60.0%, which is the lowest value in the period shown. • The annotation "Change from previous quarter: DOWN" emphasizes the recent negative trend. Summary : This line chart shows the EBIT margin and adjusted EBIT margin over seven quarters, from Q2 2024 to Q1 2026, highlighting a peak in Q1 2025 and a sharp decline in Q1 2026. line chart: Title & Axes : • Title: "EBIT MARGIN" • Subtitle: "Change from previous quarter: DOWN" • X-axis: Quarters (Q2 24, Q3 24, Q4 24, Q1 25, Q2 25, Q3 25, Q4 25, Q1 26) • Y-axis: EBIT Margin (%) with tick labels at 45.0%, 50.0%, 55.0%, 60.0%, 65.0% Data Points : • EBIT Margin (solid line): – Q2 24: ~50.0% – Q3 24: ~57.0% – Q4 24: ~61.0% – Q1 25: ~65.0% – Q2 25: ~62.0% – Q3 25: ~62.0% – Q4 25: ~61.0% – Q1 26: ~48.0% • Adjusted EBIT Margin (dashed line): closely tracks the solid line, with minor deviations, especially at peaks and troughs. Design Encodings : • EBIT Margin: solid blue line • Adjusted EBIT Margin: red dashed line • Shaded area under the lines (light blue) • "DOWN" in red with a downward arrow indicates a negative change from the previous quarter Distribution & Trends : • Both series rise steadily from Q2 24, peaking at Q1 25 (~65.0%) • Margins plateau from Q2 25 to Q4 25 (~61–62%) • Sharp decline in Q1 26 to below 50.0% Analysis : • EBIT margin and adjusted EBIT margin both show strong growth from Q2 24 to Q1 25, followed by a plateau, then a significant drop in Q1 26. • The close tracking of the two lines suggests minimal adjustment differences. • The most notable feature is the abrupt decline in Q1 26, highlighted by the "DOWN" annotation. Summary : This line chart shows the net margin and adjusted net margin over time from Q2 2024 to Q1 2026, highlighting a recent downward change in Q1 2026. line chart: Title & Axes : • Title: "NET MARGIN" • X-axis: Quarters from Q2 24 to Q1 26 (labels: Q2 24, Q3 24, Q4 24, Q1 25, Q2 25, Q3 25, Q4 25, Q1 26) • Y-axis: Percentage scale from 40.0% to 60.0% (tick marks at 40.0%, 45.0%, 50.0%, 55.0%, 60.0%) Data Points : • Solid line: Net Margin • Dashed red line: Adjusted Net Margin • Both series rise from Q2 24, peak between Q4 24 and Q1 25, remain elevated through Q4 25, then drop sharply in Q1 26. • Approximate values (from visual estimation): – Q2 24: Net Margin ~43%, Adjusted ~41% – Q4 24: Net Margin ~56%, Adjusted ~54% – Q1 25: Net Margin ~58%, Adjusted ~55% – Q4 25: Net Margin ~55%, Adjusted ~53% – Q1 26: Net Margin ~41%, Adjusted ~40% Design Encodings : • Solid line for Net Margin, dashed red line for Adjusted Net Margin. • Shaded area under the Net Margin line. • "Change from previous quarter: DOWN▼" in red text at the top right. Distribution & Trends : • Both series show a steady increase from Q2 24 to a peak around Q1 25. • Margins remain relatively high and stable through Q4 25. • Both series experience a sharp decline in Q1 26. FINANCIAL SONAR™: REALITY RADAR ON COMPANY PERFORMANCE NASDAQQGS NVDA NVIDIA CORPORATION ────────────────────────────── OVERALL RATING FOR 1ST QUARTER 2026 HOLD REGION NORTH AMERICA INDUSTRY SEMICONDUCTORS AND SEMICONDUCTOR EQUIPMENT DEFINITIONS Adjusted Net Income: Adjusted Net Income is a company’s reported net income less adjustments for one-time and non-operating items yielding a more realistic picture of a company’s ongoing earnings. Accruals – Forecasted and Actual: The comparison of forecasted and actual accruals identifies a discretionary build not attributable to a company’s sales growth, and could be a sign of poor earnings quality. For our purposes, the forecasted accrual component is an aggregate measurement of total accruals (short-term balance sheet accounts) that distinguishes between “normalized” and “extraordinary” accruals. The normalized accruals are based on historical relationships between sales and accruals and are dynamically adjusted over time to account for changes in the ratio between these two variables. Normally, short term accruals will grow as sales grow – i.e., the “normalized” measure. Discretionary accruals are the portion of accruals that are in excess of the base factor and therefore exceed the normal and are “extraordinary”. **Adjusted Operating Cash Flow:** Adjusted Operating Cash Flow is reported operating cash flow less adjustments for one-time and non-operating items yielding a more realistic picture of a company’s ongoing cash flow from operations. **Adjusted Free Cash Flow:** Adjusted Free Cash Flow is reported operating cash flow less adjustments for one-time, non-operating items and capital expenditures. This provides a more realistic picture of a company’s ongoing cash generation from operations after capital investments. **Flow Ratio:** The Flow Ratio is a measurement of management’s effectiveness in managing its working capital to maximize the company’s cash flows. The measure is a ratio of a company’s non-cash current assets to its non-interest bearing short-term liabilities.– These non-cash assets include items such as accounts receivable (which are essentially interest-free loans to customers) and inventory (which is subject to obsolescence or spoilage). The non-interest bearing liabilities are essentially interest-free loans to the company. A lower ratio implies tighter cash management for a company as it has less cash tied up in non-cash current assets and is able to utilize interest free loans from suppliers. Cash Flow Return on Investment: Cash Flow ROI is a measure of a company’s ability to generate operating cash flow from its invested capital. Many analysts consider this measure preferable to an earnings return measure such as ROE since cash flow is considered a more reliable measure. **Adjusted Cash Flow Return on Investment:** Adjusted Cash Flow ROI is a measure of the ability to generate operating cash flow from its investment in capital calculated using a company’s adjusted cash flow. **Debt Coverage:** Debt Coverage is a measure of a company's ability to cover its debt obligations with cash flow it generated from continuing operations. **Adjusted Debt Coverage**: Adjusted Debt Coverage is a measure of a company's ability to cover its debt obligations with cash flow it generated from continuing operations, calculated using a company's adjusted cash flow. **Adjusted Return on Invested Capital:** Adjusted ROIC assesses a company's efficiency at allocating the capital to profitable investments using a company's adjusted net income (see above) yielding a measure of how well a company is using its capital to generate returns. **Adjusted EBIT Margin:** Adjusted EBIT Margin is a measure of a company's earnings before interest and income taxes less adjustments for one-time and non-operating items divided by a company's sales. **Adjusted Net Margin:** Adjusted Net Margin is a measure of a company's net income less adjustments for one-time and non-operating items divided by a company's sales. Return on Incremental Invested Capital: ROIIC measures the relationship between incremental investment and incremental net operating profit after tax. This provides a measure of the returns a company is earning on recent investments rather than all investments as measured by ROIC. **Cash Conversion Cycle:** The Cash Conversion Cycle measures the number of days working capital is tied up from the date of purchase of raw materials until the collection of cash from the sale of the product. **Debt to Tangible Equity**: Debt to Tangible Equity is a ratio of a company's debt to equity less adjustments for goodwill and other intangible assets yielding tangible equity. **Debt to Tangible Assets:** Debt to Tangible Assets is a ratio of a company's debt to total assets less adjustments for goodwill and other intangible assets. **Price/Adjusted Earnings:** Adjusted Price/Earnings is a relative valuation measure comparing a company’s share price to its adjusted net income. Price/Adjusted Cash Flow: Adjusted Price/Cash Flow is a relative valuation measure comparing a company’s share price to its adjusted cash flow. **Price/Adjusted Earnings Growth:** Adjusted Price/Earnings Growth is a relative valuation measure comparing a company’s share price to its growth in adjusted earnings. © 2025 Jefferson Research & Management Report prepared on **July 11, 2025** **Page 10 of 11** www.jeffersonresearch.com logo: Jefferson Research Design Elements : • The logo consists of three stylized maroon diagonal lines on the left, resembling the letter "J" or abstract marks. • To the right of the icon, the text "Jefferson Research" appears in a serif font, colored in dark blue. • The text is horizontally aligned with the icon, with "Jefferson" and "Research" on the same line. • The background is white, and there are no additional taglines or graphical elements. Dimensions & Placement : • The icon is approximately square and positioned to the left of the text. • The text height matches the icon height for visual balance. Analysis : • The logo uses a combination of maroon and dark blue to convey professionalism and trust. • The serif font and simple icon suggest a focus on research, tradition, and reliability. FINANCIAL SONAR™: REALITY RADAR ON COMPANY PERFORMANCE NASDAQGS NVDA NVIDIA CORPORATION ________________________________________ OVERALL RATING FOR 1ST QUARTER 2026 HOLD REGION NORTH AMERICA INDUSTRY SEMICONDUCTORS AND SEMICONDUCTOR EQUIPMENT ABOUT THE FINANCIAL SONAR™ REPORT & METHODOLOGY The Jefferson Financial Sonar™ ratings system classifies companies into three categories: Buy, Hold and Sell. The Financial Sonar rating is the result of a point scoring system derived from the five main criteria. The more negative the rating, the more likely the overall rating will be a Sell. More positive criteria will support an Overall Rating of Buy. Jefferson Research & Management has developed the Financial Sonar™ Rating System which is based upon five analytical criteria: Earnings Quality, Cash Flow, Operating Efficiency, Balance Sheet, and Valuation. The first four criteria are rated in one of four categories (best to worst): Strongest, Strong, Weak, Weakest. Valuation is also rated in one of four categories (best to worst): Least Risk, Low Risk, Medium Risk, Most Risk. ABOUT JEFFERSON RESEARCH & MANAGEMENT Jefferson Research & Management is an independent investment research and advisory firm founded in 1989 and based in Portland, Oregon. The firm has been providing fundamental research to institutional and individual clients for more than 20 years. Financial Sonar™ ratings are based on a proprietary rating system developed by Jefferson Research & Management that measures the changes in company fundamentals using information from financial statements. **DISCLAIMER** This report is for information purposes only for clients of Jefferson Research & Management and in no way should be interpreted as a complete investment recommendation. A reference to a particular investment or security, a rating or any observation concerning an investment that is part of the Content is not a recommendation to buy, sell or hold such investment or security, does not address the suitability of an investment or security and should not be relied on as investment advice. INDUSTRY SEMICONDUCTORS AND SEMICONDUCTOR EQUIPMENT

**OUR EVALUATION OF NVDA**

NVIDIA Corporation is showing strong Earnings Quality, Cash Flow Quality, Operating Efficiency and Balance Sheet Quality, but Valuation suggests a higher amount of price risk. When combined, NVDA deserves a HOLD rating.

The Operating Efficiency rating improved on the strength of better margins. Though this dimension and all of the others were either stronger or unchanged at worst, it was not sufficient to raise the overall rating.

REGION NORTH AMERICA  
INDUSTRY SEMICONDUCTORS AND SEMICONDUCTOR EQUIPMENT

EARNINGS QUALITY: STRONGEST
Earnings quality has long been analyzed and used by investors as a measure of the fundamental quality of the company and its future prospects. Companies may be including certain items that increase reported earnings and often the amount of cash flow supporting the earnings may be weak. Jefferson adjusts for these kinds of items and other anomalies to produce an adjusted earnings number that more accurately reflects ongoing business fundamentals at NVIDIA Corporation. Reported earnings are compared to the Jefferson adjusted earnings as a means to gauge earnings quality. Also measured is the amount of cash flow that underpins earnings.

The earnings quality for NVDA remains STRONGEST.

Though the reported net income dropped to 18,775M from 22,091M in the previous quarter, the quality of that reported net income improved. In addition, operating cash flow increased during the last quarter to 27,414M from 16,629M, and the ratio of operating cash flow to earnings has also improved. Though both Earnings Quality measures improved, the rating for NVDA is already a STRONGEST, the best possible rating.

OPERATING EFFICIENCY: STRONG  
The ability of NVIDIA Corporation to earn a profit is in part the result of how rapidly it converts its collection of assets into revenues and the resulting earnings and cash flow margins available. Operating Efficiency is measured by a combination of factors including: return on invested capital (ROIC), gross margin, EBIT margin, asset turnover, equity turnover, and lastly Staff, General, and Administrative costs as a percentage of sales (SGA).
The operating efficiency rating for NVDA improved from WEAK to STRONG as the return on incremental investment capital and SGA costs improved since the last quarter.
In addition, the SGA costs improved from 2.5% to 2.4% of sales. The lower SGA costs indicate that NVDA has decreased the amount of revenue devoted to overhead costs.

BALANCE SHEET QUALITY: STRONG
The balance sheet shows the ability of NVIDIA Corporation to pay its bills and fund future growth. It also provides clues to aggressive accounting since reported earnings that do not generate cash flow generally end up somewhere on the balance sheet. The following are analyzed in determining balance sheet quality: quick ratio, current ratio, cash position, accounts receivable days sales outstanding (AR DSOs), and number of days inventory is held prior to sale to customers (Inv Days).

The balance sheet rating for NVDA remains STRONG as the  cash position, AR DSOs, debt/assets, and debt/equity strengthened over the last quarter while the current ratio, quick ratio and Inv Days weakened.

Even though the cash position improved from 43,210M to 53,691M, the decline in the current ratio offset this by deteriorating from 4.4X to 3.4X. The lower current ratio indicates that NVDA has decreased the amount of current assets relative to current liabilities.

DEFINITIONS

Adjusted Net Income: Adjusted Net Income is a company’s reported net income less adjustments for one-time and non-operating items yielding a more realistic picture of a company’s ongoing earnings.

Accruals – Forecasted and Actual: The comparison of forecasted and actual accruals identifies a discretionary build not attributable to a company’s sales growth, and could be a sign of poor earnings quality. For our purposes, the forecasted accrual component is an aggregate measurement of total accruals (short-term balance sheet accounts) that distinguishes between “normalized” and “extraordinary” accruals. The normalized accruals are based on historical relationships between sales and accruals and are dynamically adjusted over time to account for changes in the ratio between these two variables. Normally, short term accruals will grow as sales grow – i.e., the “normalized” measure. Discretionary accruals are the portion of accruals that are in excess of the base factor and therefore exceed the normal and are “extraordinary”.

**Adjusted Operating Cash Flow:** Adjusted Operating Cash Flow is reported operating cash flow less adjustments for one-time and non-operating items yielding a more realistic picture of a company’s ongoing cash flow from operations.

**Adjusted Free Cash Flow:** Adjusted Free Cash Flow is reported operating cash flow less adjustments for one-time, non-operating items and capital expenditures. This provides a more realistic picture of a company’s ongoing cash generation from operations after capital investments.

**Flow Ratio:** The Flow Ratio is a measurement of management’s effectiveness in managing its working capital to maximize the company’s cash flows. The measure is a ratio of a company’s non-cash current assets to its non-interest bearing short-term liabilities.– These non-cash assets include items such as accounts receivable (which are essentially interest-free loans to customers) and inventory (which is subject to obsolescence or spoilage). The non-interest bearing liabilities are essentially interest-free loans to the company. A lower ratio implies tighter cash management for a company as it has less cash tied up in non-cash current assets and is able to utilize interest free loans from suppliers.

Cash Flow Return on Investment: Cash Flow ROI is a measure of a company’s ability to generate operating cash flow from its invested capital. Many analysts consider this measure preferable to an earnings return measure such as ROE since cash flow is considered a more reliable measure.

**Adjusted Cash Flow Return on Investment:** Adjusted Cash Flow ROI is a measure of the ability to generate operating cash flow from its investment in capital calculated using a company’s adjusted cash flow.
**Debt Coverage:** Debt Coverage is a measure of a company's ability to cover its debt obligations with cash flow it generated
from continuing operations.

**Adjusted Debt Coverage**: Adjusted Debt Coverage is a measure of a company's ability to cover its debt obligations with cash flow it generated from continuing operations, calculated using a company's adjusted cash flow.

**Adjusted Return on Invested Capital:** Adjusted ROIC assesses a company's efficiency at allocating the capital to profitable investments using a company's adjusted net income (see above) yielding a measure of how well a company is using its capital to generate returns.

**Adjusted EBIT Margin:** Adjusted EBIT Margin is a measure of a company's earnings before interest and income taxes less adjustments for one-time and non-operating items divided by a company's sales.
**Adjusted Net Margin:** Adjusted Net Margin is a measure of a company's net income less adjustments for one-time and non-operating items divided by a company's sales.

Return on Incremental Invested Capital: ROIIC measures the relationship between incremental investment and incremental net operating profit after tax. This provides a measure of the returns a company is earning on recent investments rather than all investments as measured by ROIC.

**Cash Conversion Cycle:** The Cash Conversion Cycle measures the number of days working capital is tied up from the date of purchase of raw materials until the collection of cash from the sale of the product.
**Debt to Tangible Equity**: Debt to Tangible Equity is a ratio of a company's debt to equity less adjustments for goodwill and other intangible assets yielding tangible equity.
**Debt to Tangible Assets:** Debt to Tangible Assets is a ratio of a company's debt to total assets less adjustments for goodwill and other intangible assets.
**Price/Adjusted Earnings:** Adjusted Price/Earnings is a relative valuation measure comparing a company’s share price to its adjusted net income.
Price/Adjusted Cash Flow: Adjusted Price/Cash Flow is a relative valuation measure comparing a company’s share price to its adjusted cash flow.
**Price/Adjusted Earnings Growth:** Adjusted Price/Earnings Growth is a relative valuation measure comparing a company’s share price to its growth in adjusted earnings.

ABOUT THE FINANCIAL SONAR™ REPORT & METHODOLOGY

The Jefferson Financial Sonar™ ratings system classifies companies into three categories: Buy, Hold and Sell. The Financial Sonar rating is the result of a point scoring system derived from the five main criteria. The more negative the rating, the more likely the overall rating will be a Sell. More positive criteria will support an Overall Rating of Buy.

Jefferson Research & Management has developed the Financial Sonar™ Rating System which is based upon five analytical criteria: Earnings Quality, Cash Flow, Operating Efficiency, Balance Sheet, and Valuation. The first four criteria are rated in one of four categories (best to worst): Strongest, Strong, Weak, Weakest. Valuation is also rated in one of four categories (best to worst): Least Risk, Low Risk, Medium Risk, Most Risk.

ABOUT JEFFERSON RESEARCH & MANAGEMENT

Jefferson Research & Management is an independent investment research and advisory firm founded in 1989 and based in Portland, Oregon. The firm has been providing fundamental research to institutional and individual clients for more than 20 years. Financial Sonar™ ratings are based on a proprietary rating system developed by Jefferson Research & Management that measures the changes in company fundamentals using information from financial statements.
